Abstract
=================

Background
-----------------
Current knowledge:
Humeral shaft fractures are a common fracture type seen in our emergency department. Most are treated surgically. There are several treatment options, including closed reduction and percutaneous stabilization with intramedullary nail or plate fixation. Recently, the use of bending plates in three-part fractures has become increasingly popular. In these fractures, the humerus is shortened by 2 centimeters and then reduced and fixed with two additional screws in order to improve the biomechanical properties. Few studies have been published on the use of bending plates in the periprosthetic humerus. There is a risk that these plates are also ineffective in the elderly as they are osteoporotic and may also sustain bone loss around the implant. The use of new screw types (locking and cannonball compression screws) increases the stability of these osteosynthetic plates.

Hypothesis:
The hypothesis is that plate fixation of the humerus with use of new cannonball compression screws is a safe and effective treatment modality in the osteoporotic periprosthetic humeral shaft. 

Objective
-----------------
To assess the clinical outcomes after bending plate fixation of the prosthetic humeral shaft with cannonball compression screws.

Design
-----------------
This is a prospective observational cohort study with a 12 -month follow-up.

[INTRODUCTION] The treatment of acute humeral shaft fractures in children remains a challenge for surgeons. There are several options, including closed reduction and percutaneous pinning, external fixation, and open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). Although each treatment has its own advantages and disadvantages, there is no clear gold standard for humeral shaft fractures.
The goal of this study is to compare several treatment options for humeral shaft fractures in children and evaluate their effectiveness in terms of clinical and radiological outcomes. Abstract:
Background: Radiation therapy (RT) is a key component in the treatment of many cancers. Hypoxia, or lack of oxygen supply, is considered a major factor of cancer treatment resistance. To date, methods to target hypoxic tumor cells are limited. MRI sequences that enable the mapping of intra‐tumor hypoxia have shown potential for improving treatment planning and delivery. In this prospective, multicenter cohort study, we aim to generate a large dataset of MRI-based maps of intra‐tumoral hypoxia (iHyp) in patients undergoing RT for prostate cancer and to explore their prognostic and predictive potential. Methods: The study population will include male patients ≥18 years, with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate (T2‐T4), scheduled to receive RT with curative intent, and an ECOG performance status of 0 or 1. Patients will undergo MRI with diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) and T2* sequences. A third MRI sequence, diffusion‐weighted, MR thermometry, will be conducted in a subset of patients undergoing RT, to measure the tumor's metabolic response to therapy. Hypoxia, or lack of oxygen supply, is known to be a major factor in tumor resistance to radiotherapy. By generating 3D maps of intra-tumoral hypoxia and studying their evolution during treatment, we can better understand the impact of hypoxia on treatment outcomes. This information will help us adapt the doses of radiotherapy to each session based on the daily level of intra-tumor radiosensitivity. Ultimately, this outcome measure aims to improve treatment effectiveness and personalize treatment plans for each patient. 

Study design and objectives for multicenter, prospective, non-interventional, national clinical research: a national multicenter cohort to build an experimental platform of hypoxia imaging and its clinical application

Abstract:
Radiotherapy is an essential component of multidisciplinary cancer treatment, which requires effective evaluation of its effect on tumor control and patient risk stratification. However, current imaging approaches cannot provide quantitative information on hypoxia, a key prognostic parameter. The study aims to develop an imaging method to quantify hypoxia in patients undergoing radiotherapy for curative or palliative purposes. The experimental platform will consist of two main steps: a preclinical study aimed at validating the imaging method, and a clinical study to develop a quantitative imaging method in patients treated with radiotherapy. 


Introduction
Studies have found that a hypoxic tumor microenvironment can reduce the effectiveness of radiotherapy, and hypoxia may be one of the main reasons for radioresistance (Zhang et al. 2013; Huang et al. 2016). As a result, clinical management of patients with hypoxic tumors requires an accurate evaluation of tumor hypoxia. A hypoxic tumor microenvironment usually indicates that tumor cells are refractory to radiotherapy, and hypoxia is considered to be caused by the abnormal microenvironment of tumor vessels, which is characterized by an irregular blood vessel structure and high blood flow. Therefore, hypoxia assessment is expected to complement angiogenesis therapy, radiotherapy, and immunotherapy as a clinical treatment method for hypoxic tumors (Wang et al. 2015; Qin et al. 2019). Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This Phase 1b dose-escalation and expansion study will assess the safety and efficacy of RP103 in patients with advanced or metastatic renal cell carcinoma (mRCC). Patients will receive multiple treatments of RP103 in cycles of 18 days in the dose escalation phase (Phase 1) and two doses of RP103 in the expansion phase (Phase 2). Each cycle will consist of a 10 milligram (mg)/meter squared (m2) dose of RP103 followed by a one-week rest period. Blood samples will be collected at various time points throughout the study.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the safety and tolerability of RP103 in patients with advanced or metastatic cancer. The secondary objective is to assess the efficacy of RP103 in terms of objective response rate (including complete response, partial response, and stable disease), progression free survival (PFS), TTP, and OS. Exploratory objectives include assessing the effect of RP103 on cancer cell proliferation and apoptosis, as well as pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters. 10 patients will be enrolled in Phase 1 and treated with RP103 at a dose of 50 mg/m2. If fewer than 3 patients experience dose limiting toxicity (DLT), the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) will be determined at the beginning of Phase 2, and 3 additional patients will be enrolled at the same dose level. If more than 3 patients experience DLT, or if the MTD is not reached, the trial will be terminated. Phases 2a (interested patients 1 and 2 below) and 2b (interested patients 3 and 4 below) include a rolling design with a 50% dose reduction over four doses. The measure description for the area under the curve (AUC) would be the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time zero to the last quantifiable concentration (AUClast) and the AUC from time zero through infinity (AUCinf). The measure description for the maximum concentration (Cmax) would be the maximum observed plasma concentration of SOT201. The measure description for the time to maximum concentration (Tmax), would be the time at which the maximum observed plasma concentration of SOT201 was reached. The measure description for the pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) would be the concentration of SOT201 in the blood before a dose of the drug. The measure descriptions for the ORR, DoR, iCBR, and iPFS would include the percentages of patients with complete response (CR), partial response (PR), stable disease (SD), progressive disease (PD), and overall survival (OS). The measure description for the incidence of ADAs against SOT201 would be the percentage of patients with positive results for anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a prospective, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial in 30 patients admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of Hospital San José Cisneros (HSCJ). The hypothesis is that non-invasive neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) of the tongue and masticatory muscles will improve airway protective reflexes in patients on invasive mechanical ventilation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a prospective, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial in 30 patients admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of Hospital San José Cisneros (HSCJ). A total of 30 patients will be enrolled in the study and randomly allocated to two groups: the intervention group (Group A - neuromuscular electrical stimulation) and the control group (Group B - no stimulation). The hypothesis is that non-invasive neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) of the tongue and masticatory muscles will improve airway protective reflexes in patients on invasive mechanical ventilation. This study will be composed of three phases: Phase I: A minimum sample of 6 patients will be recruited before the start of the study, with one subject per group, who will act as a pilot for Phase II. If the results in this pilot phase are promising, the second phase of the study will be performed (Phase II). In Phase II, a total of five participants will be enrolled and assigned to the two groups (Group A - n = 2 and Group B - n = 3). The objective of this pilot phase is to determine the feasibility of NMES implementation and the study itself. Objective: To examine the association between the implementation of the COVID‐19 vaccination and the increase of influenza‐like illness (ILI) in pediatric patients attending 52 pediatric emergency departments (PEDs) in Japan in the weeks immediately following the start of vaccinations.Methods: We conducted a prospective study for influenza‐like cases of febrile patients over 36 months old who presented between November 2020 and May 2021 at each of the 52 PEDs participating in a network. After excluding incomplete cases, multiple testing was conducted to identify time periods in which statistically significant increases in weekly ILI incidence occurred. To determine the possible impact of vaccination on ILI incidence, we divided PEDs into four groups based on vaccination dates and used linear mixed effects modeling to compare ILI incidence within the first four weeks between each group.Results: A total of 24,974 cases were analyzed and 17,369 were excluded according to the inclusion and exclusion criteria (9222 of 9948 cases were vaccinated and 8147 of 16,026 cases were not vaccinated). Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To determine whether a multifocal electrical stimulation (MES) device significantly improves the functional recovery of patients after stroke or other neuromuscular disorders.DESIGN: Prospective and randomized.SETTING: An inpatient rehabilitation service and clinical laboratories in a university‐affiliated teaching hospital.PATIENTS: A total of 61 patients, all with a recent neurological injury, randomly assigned to treatment (29) or usual therapy (32) groups.INTERVENTION: Patients in the treatment group received MES therapy for 90 minutes, 5 days a week for 4 weeks. Their usual therapy continued as well.MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE: Functional recovery, as measured by Fugel‐Meyer (motor) assessment before treatment, after treatment, and 12 weeks later.RESULTS: Patients treated with MES for 4 weeks were significantly better on Fugel‐Meyer motor assessment than those who underwent usual rehabilitation. The functional benefits lasted for 12 weeks after therapy ended. Analysis of the data revealed that only 2 patients in the treatment group had residual pain after 12 weeks.CONCLUSIONS: The results of this study suggest that MES is effective at improving the functional recovery of patients with neuromuscular disorders, and that this therapy may be less painful than conventional methods of treatment.

Abstract:
Background: In 2018, the HIPAA omnibus ruled that health care institutions could disclose protected health information for non‐research purposes, such as quality improvement. Objective: To determine the impact of adding a “care coordination” communication to patient's care between primary care physician visits by a social worker for adult patients seen >2 years in the outpatient primary care clinic of a safety net hospital in Central Texas. This randomized pilot RCT tested the ability of patient‐centered communication to improve outpatient clinical outcomes over a 9 month period. Methods: We used a novel randomized pilot trial to test in a patient subset (n=28) the impact of a care coordination communication (C3) from a licensed social worker over 9 months compared to usual care. C3 was performed prior to the PCP visit or after clinical history obtained at the office. Outcomes were patient reported symptoms: depression, smoking, alcohol and drug use, quality of life and medical record data: outpatient visits and hospitalization in a 9 month time period. Data were collected prior to the intervention and then at 9 months post intervention. Patient reported outcomes were collected online and an average value was calculated. Outpatient visit and hospitalization data was collected over a 9‐month period including data at the time of the first primary care visit and hospitalization if this occurred prior to starting the pilot trial. Results: C3 resulted in a non‐significant improvement in patient reported outcomes: 8 in the C3 group and 6 in the usual care group were depressed (z=1.606, p=0.109). In a subset (n=6) of the patients, a significant decrease in visits to PCP (12 vs. 3 visits, chi‐square 2.46 p=0.03), and emergency room visits (1 vs. 3, chi‐square 2.46 p = 0.04). Discussion: This study demonstrates a potential positive impact of a non‐research intervention on non‐research outcomes for underserved adult patients. We demonstrate for the first time a potential impact of social work communication

Introduction
Chronic pain is a prevalent problem, affecting more than 100 million Americans.1 It is defined as pain that lasts more than 3 months and affects a large part of the population2 and is one of the main causes of disability and loss of independence3. Chronic pain is also associated with a higher risk of developing drug addiction and overuse of analgesic drugs, which can lead to tolerance, dependence, and misuse.4 In addition, individuals with chronic pain are more likely to develop other mental health problems, including depression, anxiety, and sleep disturbances.2,5 These mental health comorbidities are often difficult to treat and may have a significant impact on patients' quality of life.6
The prevalence of chronic pain in patients with substance use disorders is higher than in the general population.7 Studies have shown that up to 85% of patients with drug dependencies have chronic pain.8 It is estimated that up to 81% of patients with alcohol use disorder and 95% of patients with opioid use disorder have chronic pain.9 Chronic pain is also more prevalent in patients with stimulant use disorder, such as cocaine and amphetamine use disorder, with a prevalence of up to 70%.10 These data suggest that chronic pain may be an important contributing factor to the development of substance use disorders11 and vice versa.12
There are many explanations for the high prevalence of chronic pain in patients with substance use disorders. First, these patients may be more likely to use substances to self-medicate their pain, which can lead to an increase in tolerance, dependence, and overuse.13 Moreover, chronic pain is often associated with increased stress and psychological distress, which can increase the risk of substance use.14,15 Finally, there are biological mechanisms linking chronic pain to substance use disorders, including changes in the brain's reward system and neurotransmitters.16

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with progressive respiratory failure requiring oxygen supplementation due to severe bronchiectasis who cannot be treated with surgical treatment, and severe restrictive lung disease requiring lung transplantation were enrolled and randomly assigned to intervention and non-intervention groups respectively in this study. After 3 months of follow-up, the results of blood gas analysis, 6MWT (six-minute walk test), FVC ventilator expiratory volume, DLCO diffusion capacity, PFT (pulmonary function test), 6MWD (6-minute walk distance), and QOL (quality-of-life) were compared with those before administration.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Bronchiectasis is a complex disease with diverse etiologies and significant morbidity and mortality. Patients with progressive lung disease often require long-term oxygen therapy due to poor lung function or respiratory failure. Currently, lung transplantation is the only effective treatment for bronchiectasis-related progressive respiratory failure. However, few patients were able to undergo lung transplantation due to lack of donors, high medical risks, and the high economic burden of surgical treatment, which was not suitable for Chinese patients. The long-term use of high-dose prednisone in bronchiectasis patients with progressive lung disease could cause serious side effects such as osteoporosis, adrenal insufficiency, and diabetes. In our research group, a previous study revealed that human airway epithelial cells and human lung primary cells expressed 63+ in bronchiectasis. Recent studies have shown that 63+ Cells are mainly located in the airway of children with infectious bronchiectasis. We have developed the world's first 63+ cell therapy drug "Changbao-01", which

Furthermore, targeting Che-1 can potentially reduce the dose of chemotherapy, leading to fewer adverse side effects. I look forward to the next steps of the study.

Abstract:
Introduction/Objective: Che‐1 in the chromatin and epigenetic modifications is involved in tumor‐associated inflammation and tumor proliferation/survival. Here, we evaluated the expression and clinical impact of Che‐1 and its effect on multiple myeloma (MM). Methods: We conducted a prospective clinical trial and enrolled 255 newly diagnosed patients with MM, including 80 patients with high Che‐1 expression, between February 2021 until December 2021. Che‐1 expression was evaluated by immunohistochemistry (IHC) of bone marrow samples. In addition, 60 newly diagnosed MM patients were selected for Che‐1 siRNA to explore the role of Che‐1 in cell-mediated inflammation. Clinical outcomes were compared between high Che‐1 expression group and low Che‐1 expression group. Results: High Che‐1 expression was associated with International Staging System (ISS), renal function, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and prognostic markers (P53, p16, and TP53) levels. We observed that high Che‐1 expression group had worse event-free survival (EFS) than low Che‐1 expression group (Cox regression hazard ratio (HR) = 3.875, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.276-11.775, p = 0.019, HR = 0.029, 95% CI 0.001-0.068, p < 0.001). Che‐1 siRNA inhibited cell‐mediated inflammation and cell proliferation by repressing IL‐6 and IL‐8 and then improving overall survival (OS) (p = 0.042). Conclusions: Che‐1 may promote MM by activating inflammatory chemokines such as IL‐

Thank you for your feedback. The trial is designed to assess the benefit of Che-1 inhibition for MM patients. We look forward to analyzing the results and applying this information to future studies and treatments.

Abstract:
[BACKGROUND] Dysregulation of gene expression is a hallmark of multiple myeloma (MM) tumorigenesis. One mechanism underlying the aberrant gene expression pattern is through the recruitment of chromatin modifiers, such as the BET family of bromodomain proteins, to specific loci. Inhibition of BET family proteins has proven to be an effective therapeutic strategy for MM. Here, we assessed the use of Che‐1 inhibitors, a non‐BET specific family of Bromodomain proteins, as a therapeutic strategy for MM. [METHODS] In this prospective, single‐center, randomized, open‐label, Phase Ib clinical trial, 45 MM patients were screened and assessed for eligibility. Eligible patients were then randomized into the treatment and control groups, and two courses of MCP‐154 and venetoclax treatment was administered to the treatment group. [RESULTS] Our results revealed that the treatment group had a 20% improvement in progression‐free survival (PFS) compared to the control group, with no significant difference in overall survival. Additionally, there was a delay in the development of minimal residual disease in the treatment group, suggesting that treatment with Che‐1 inhibitors may delay the progression of MM in this patient population. [CONCLUSIONS] These results suggest that Che‐1 inhibitors may be a promising therapeutic strategy for MM patients. However, further studies are needed to determine the long‐term effects of Che‐1 inhibitor therapy on PFS and other clinical outcomes.

I'm glad to hear that you're comfortable with the measures we've selected. The outcomes we're proposing aim to advance our understanding of Multiple Myeloma treatment, focusing on Che-1's role in chromatin remodeling and gene expression, as well as evaluating Che-1's potential as a therapeutic target. We'll continue to monitor progress and ensure the measures provide valuable information to move our research forward.

Abstract:
Objective: The aim of this study is to demonstrate that the use of a structured interview, designed to elicit a comprehensive range of symptoms, increases the number and type of self‐reported symptoms in cancer survivors. Method: 400 patients were recruited from the Cancer Support Group for follow up after treatment. The patients were randomized to two groups: an intervention or a control group. The intervention group received a questionnaire developed by the research group, the Control group received standard care. Both questionnaires covered physical, psycho‐social, and spiritual aspects of well‐ being. Results: 250 patients completed the questionnaires (intervention and control), which contained 200 question about symptoms, experiences, opinions, and beliefs. The intervention group identified a significantly higher number of symptoms than the control group, and their symptoms were more diverse. Additionally, the group also felt that the interview helped them to better express their concerns. Conclusion: Structured interviews are useful methods in clinical practice for assessing the health needs and concerns of oncology patients. They also help to identify previously unrecognized symptoms and psychosocial needs in this population. 2012 Springer‐Verlag Berlin Heidelberg ‐.

Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to investigate changes in skeletal muscle composition and structure during high‐intensity, short‐duration physical training (HIIT) among middle‐aged women. The study sample consisted of 18 women (20‐35 years of age) with 4‐18 weeks inactive period. All subjects took part in a ten‐week HIIT program, which was designed according to their physical fitness. The intervention took place twice or three times per week, and consisted of 16 short bouts of high‐intensity running and 1 longer period of moderate‐intensity jogging or walking. The intervention was preceded by assessment of muscle strength and composition. Muscle strength was assessed by one repetition maximum (1RM) in leg press and in knee extension. Muscle structure and cross‐sectional area were assessed by B‐mode ultrasonography (US). The results indicated that there was an increase in muscle strength in both leg press and knee extension after the ten‐week HIIT program. In quadriceps muscles, muscle composition was not changed, but a trend towards reduction of the intramuscular fat content was observed. Muscle cross‐sectional area and fiber diameter were not changed. Muscle strength increased both in type I and type II fibers, whereas no changes were observed in muscle composition or structure in calf muscles. We conclude that HIIT is effective in improving muscle strength, independent of exercise modality or muscle type.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Sickle cell trait (SCT) carriers (defined as individuals who have only one copy of the haemoglobin S gene, and are heterozygous for sickle cell disease) were shown to be at a greater risk than the general population for sudden death occurring early in the course of moderate intensity physical exercise. However, the exact mechanism by which SCT carriers are at greater risk is not understood. There have been several studies that have used various imaging modalities to try and elucidate the mechanism, though with varying results. A systematic review by Hutchins et al. [6] of 11 studies identified 8 that had used cardiac MRI to identify SCT carriers. The results were conflicting with respect to the presence or absence of abnormalities in the cardiac chambers and the degree of myocardial cellularity that had been reported. Furthermore, 3 of the 4 studies that had evaluated the presence of an abnormal myocardial signal by use of inversion recovery sequences, found this abnormality in SCT carriers. There have also been a number of reports of late gadolinium enhancement (with and without hypertrabeculation) and T2‐weighted images suggestive of myocardial fibrosis in SCT carriers, as well as an increase in diastolic thickness on cardiac MRI, suggesting an increase in LV size [7]. This suggests that there is a need to better understand the underlying pathophysiological changes that occur in the heart in SCT carriers participating in exercise. It has also been postulated that cardiac MRI may be a better method than exercise stress test for detecting potential athletes at increased risk of sudden death [5]. Therefore, this study aims to determine, in SCT carriers enrolled in this study, the prevalence of subclinical cardiovascular abnormalities using cardiac MRI as compared with matched controls selected by age, gender and body mass index who do not have any known cardiovascular disorders.METHODS: Following ethical and research clearance, participants will be recruited through the use of advertising. In total, 50 healthy controls without any known cardiac pathology will be enrolled for this

Abstract:
Background: Older adults 70+ account for approximately 55% of cancer incidence in Bangladesh, and nearly 70% of these individuals are socially disadvantaged. We hypothesized that a community‐based social support model (Peer Connect) could augment the cancer care team and support the psychosocial needs of socially disadvantaged older adults with cancer. Aims: This paper presents the methodology of a planned pilot study to evaluate the feasibility of a cluster randomized control trial (RCT) of an intervention aimed at improving the psychosocial outcomes of socially disadvantaged older adults with cancer in Bangladesh. Methods: The pilot study is a mixed methods study that will be conducted concurrently with the RCT. A total of four intervention arms (i.e., focus group‐based intervention, peer support‐based intervention, peer support plus community resource referrals plus social media‐based intervention, and standard of care) and two control arms (i.e., health facility‐based peer support‐only and no intervention) will be assessed. The pilot study aims to evaluate the feasibility of the RCT methodology using a 3 + 3 + 1 sampling process. Both quantitative and qualitative data will be collected. Data saturation and data triangulation will be used to ensure the representativeness of the findings. Statistical analyses will include descriptive analysis, thematic analysis, and correlation analysis. Results: The pilot study will recruit 2084 individuals, with 521 in the focus group‐based intervention arm, 521 in the peer support‐based intervention arm, 521 in the peer support plus community resource referrals plus social media‐based intervention arm, 521 in the health facility‐based peer support‐only arm, 260 in the no intervention arm, and a small sample (estimated 21‐49 in each arm) in the primary outcome study. Discussion: The peer connect model is hypothesized to effectively address the social determinants of health in the context of older adults with cancer in Bangladesh. The results of the planned pilot study will inform the design of a full‐scale RCT to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention.

Study design
=================
Single-center, single-arm, non-randomized, open-label, dose-escalation study to investigate the safety, efficacy, and pharmacokinetics of YL201 in patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer

A single-center single-arm, non-randomized, open-label, dose-escalation study will be conducted in Japan to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and pharmacokinetics of YL201 in patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

Study objectives
=================
1. The efficacy endpoints are the objective response rate (ORR), progression-free survival (PFS), and the recommended dose for the pivotal clinical trial. The ORR will be assessed by radiographic evaluation (based on the Response Evaluation Criteria for Solid Tum

Sure! In addition to the primary objectives listed above, there are other secondary outcome measures. These include safety and tolerability of YL201 for Injection (as defined by adverse events, laboratory abnormalities, vital signs, electrocardiogram [ECG] changes, and clinical laboratory assessments), overall survival (OS), and progression-free survival (PFS). The time frame for assessing the secondary outcome measures is also approximately within 36 months. 

Now, do you have any suggestions for the statistical methods of analysis?

Certainly! The disease control rate measures the percentage of participants with confirmed best overall response of confirmed CR, PR, or stable disease (SD) to treatment. This provides a comprehensive assessment of the efficacy of YL201 in treating metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

Duration of response (DoR) measures the duration of CR or PR in participants responsive to treatment. This is a useful measure to assess the durability of clinical benefit and the potential for long-term disease control. The assessment time frame for DoR is within 36 months.

Time to objective response (TTR) is the time from the start of treatment to the first time a participant attains a confirmed CR, PR, or SD. This is a measure used to evaluate the speed of therapeutic response and provides insights into the potential for YL201 to accelerate disease response. The assessment time frame for TTR is within 36 months.

For PSA response, we measure the percentage of participants with clinically meaningful prostate-specific antigen (PSA) response (defined as a reduction of PSA level of ≥50%) and the percentage of participants with biochemical progression-free survival, both at 6 months and overall. These measures provide valuable insights into how YL201 affects the changes in PSA levels and the course of disease progression in participants with mCRPC. Overall survival measures the time from the start of treatment to death from any cause and provides a comprehensive assessment of the long-term prognosis of participants. We will also be assessing the safety and tolerability of YL201, including adverse events, laboratory abnormalities, and vital signs.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal of the study is to study how the investigational medication called ASP9174, works in people with a history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), and to collect data on the safety of study drug. This is an exploratory study. Participants will be evaluated at baseline and on specified days thereafter. Blood samples will be drawn at baseline and at specified time points during the study to determine the effects of ASP9174 on various genes and proteins.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase 2, open-label, non-randomized, multicenter exploratory study of the efficacy and safety of ASP9174 in subjects with a history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). Subjects who complete the study may receive compassionate use. Participants will be administered ASP9174 daily in 21-day treatment cycles for 5 consecutive cycles. After 5 cycles, each additional cycle will consist of 1 treatment day followed by 20 days off treatment. Participants will be evaluated at baseline and on specified days thereafter. Blood samples will be drawn at baseline and at specified time points during the study to determine the effects of ASP9174 on various genes and proteins. Participants will not be allowed on a new anticancer therapy until study completion. For participants who complete the study, subsequent therapy will be dependent upon the discretion of the investigator. If study drug is no longer required by the participant, the participant may be eligible to receive compassionate use of ASP9174 for up to 1 year after the last dosing visit.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase II, Open-Label, Multicenter Exploratory Study of ASP9174 in Subjects With a History of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma (NHL)

Conditions

Malignant Lymphoma, Non-Hodgkin, Recurrent, Solid Tumor Neoplasms, Lymphoid Neoplasm

Introduction
=================
This work is to develop a novel method using machine learning to predict the presence of a cardiac infarction within 1 month after hospital discharge.

Objective
=================
We aim to develop a predictive model with performance metrics that are superior to the currently existing systems of the Netherlands. Secondary to this study objective is to describe predictors for 1-month risk of acute myocardial infarction, such as patient characteristics or biomarkers that can be measured during hospital stay.

Study design
=================
This study is a retrospective, observational study with a secondary analysis of a dataset.

Participants
=================
Admitted, non-emergent patients of the coronary care unit (CCU) of the Amsterdam University Medical Centers (UMC).

Inclusion criteria and exclusion criteria
=================
Inclusion criteria
- Admitted patient at the CCU of the AUMC during a period of one year from March 2018 to February 2019 or during a period of one year from March 2019 to February 2020.
Exclusion criteria
- Age < 18
- In-hospital mortality by the patient
- Exclusion is performed when patient characteristics are inaccesible

Primary outcome
=================
The primary outcome is the presence of an acute myocardial infarction within 1-month after hospital discharge.  An acute myocardial infarction is defined according to Troponin values being above the 99th percentile, according to local laboratory reference.

Secondary outcomes
=================
No secondary outcomes were defined

Data collection:
=================
Clinical data collected at patient level at baseline
- Age
- Gender
- Diagnosis before admission to the CCU (such as stable angina or stable heart failure)
- Admission type (routine/admission for unstable angina pectoris or heart failure)
- Laboratory tests (CK-MB, Troponin)
- Prognostic parameters (such as comorbidity and history of cardiovascular disease)
- Time between event and diagnosis

Abstract:
Fifty‐two children, aged 6‐17 years, were randomized to receive either a novel oral chemotherapy combination or 6 courses of intravenous cisplatin, 800 mg/m4. In the oral group 33 courses (66%) was administered; in the conventional group 40 courses (77%). There were no treatment‐related side effects in the oral group. Grade 4 thrombocytopenia was noted in 13/40 patients (33%) in the cisplatin group, and 1/33 patients (3%) in the oral group had grade 1 vomiting. One year disease‐free survival in the oral group was 86%; in the cisplatin group disease‐free survival was 74% (p, not significant). The 5‐year event‐free survival in the oral group was 53% versus 47% in the cisplatin group (p, .065). No difference in overall survival was detected. This oral chemotherapy regimen is well tolerated, with a comparable toxicity profile to that of cisplatin; it achieves similar disease control, longer event‐free survival, shorter hospitalization and is more readily administered in underdeveloped centers.

For Cohort 1, the secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival by disease site (bone only vs. non-bone), overall survival (OS), toxicity profile and safety (overall and disease site-specific), and changes in quality of life. For Cohort 2, the secondary outcome measures include progression-free survival by disease site (bone only vs. non-bone), OS, toxicity profile and safety (with special emphasis on flare reaction), and changes in quality of life.

Patients in Arm 1A will undergo MDRT alongside ADT and cytotoxic chemotherapy, and patients in Arm 1B will undergo ADT and chemotherapy alone. Patients in Arm 2A will undergo MDRT alone, and patients in Arm 2B will undergo SOC ADT alone. The treatment arms in each cohort will be compared for progression-free survival (PFS) at a mean follow-up of 36 months. The efficacy and safety of the combination of FDG-PET-guided MDRT with standard of care systemic therapies (SOC) will be assessed. The primary objective of Cohort 1 is to assess the efficacy of FDG-PET-guided MDRT in combination with SOC therapies in terms of PFS, compared to SOC therapies alone in patients with mCSPC. The secondary objectives are to assess the efficacy and safety of FDG-PET-guided MDRT in combination with SOC therapies in patients with mCSPC. The primary objective of Cohort 2 is to assess the efficacy of FDG-PET-guided MDRT on disease outcomes, particularly the complete response rate. The secondary objectives are to assess the safety and efficacy of FDG-PET-guided MDRT.

Number of Arms:: 2
Target Number of Participant:: 67
Arm Type:: Experimental

Objective response rate is defined as the proportion of patients who experience either a complete response or a partial response on FDG-PET-2, confirmed by blinded independent central review, as compared to baseline (FDG-PET-1). The time frame for this measure is from randomization to first radiographic or PSA-based disease progression, or death from any cause, assessed up to 36 months.

=================
Key secondary study objectives include the ability to detect the presence of metastatic prostate cancer, to determine the impact of FDG-PET-based metastasis on overall survival and quality of life, to describe the characteristics of FDG-avid lesions in different cohorts, and to evaluate the association between FDG-PET-2 and radiographic or PSA-based disease progression or death. 
Safety Objectives include the proportion of patients with serious adverse events, the proportion of patients with adverse events leading to study discontinuation, and the overall safety profile of FDG-PET-based MDRT in combination with standard treatments.

model_response: The incidence of treatment-emergent AEs, SAEs, and AEs leading to permanent treatment discontinuation will provide critical safety data to inform decision-making regarding the long-term safety of Itepekimab in patients with COPD. These outcome measures will assess the cumulative safety profile of Itepekimab over an extended period of time.

The secondary outcome measures include the evaluation of the efficacy of Itepekimab in participants with COPD over the extended treatment period. The following outcomes will be analyzed: lung function (measured using spirometry and diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCco) testing), COPD symptoms (measured using the Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Assessment Test (C-CAT)), exacerbations of COPD, quality of life (measured using the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ)), and healthcare resource utilization. These outcomes will provide information on the long-term efficacy of Itepekimab in improving lung function, reducing COPD symptoms, and improving quality of life for participants with COPD who have received prior treatment with Itepekimab. 

Study type
=================
interventional

Condition
=================
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

Intervention
=================
Other: Study Drug (Itepekimab)
Other: Placebo


Participation Criteria
=================
Eligibility Criteria
-----------------
Inclusion Criteria: Participants who have completed the treatment period of the clinical studies EFC16750 or EFC16819. These participants will have received Itepekimab or Placebo during the parent trial and will have been randomly assigned to one of the study arms in the extension trial. Participants must meet the following criteria: Able to speak, read, and understand English or Spanish and willing to comply with protocol procedures and study assessments. In addition, participants must have a documented diagnosis of COPD and have completed the treatment period of the parent trial without evidence of any significant changes in their health status.Exclusion Criteria: Participants with a history of significant medical conditions such as unstable angina, myocardial infarction, or heart failure within the last six months will be ineligible for enrollment. Other exclusion criteria may also apply and will be evaluated during the screening process.

Ages Eligible for Study
-----------------
Minimum Age: 40 Years
Maximum Age: 85 Years

Sexes Eligible for Study
-----------------
All

Accepts Healthy Volunteers
-----------------
No

Study Plan

The secondary outcome measures are designed to provide additional information about the efficacy of Itepekenimab in improving symptoms and quality of life for participants with COPD. Secondary outcome measures are designed to evaluate the functional Itepekimab concentrations in serum, incidence of treatment-emergent anti-drug antibody responses, annualized rate of moderate-to-severe acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD), annualized rate of severe AECOPD, time to first moderate-to-severe AECOPD, time to first severe AECOPD, change from baseline of the parent studies (EFC16750, EFC16819) in Pre-BD and post-BD FEV1, the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) total score and domain scores, the EuroQol-5 Dimensions-5 Level (EQ-5D-5L) single index score, and the EuroQol Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS). 2015-2022 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group 

The primary outcome measure is the incidence of treatment-emergent AEs, SAEs, and AEs leading to treatment discontinuation, which is essential in ensuring participant safety. The annualized rate of moderate-to-severe and severe AECOPD, time to first moderate-to-severe and severe AECOPD, and Pre-BD and post-BD FEV1 changes from baseline are related to the impact of COPD on participants' daily activities and overall quality of life. These outcome measures provide further insights into the efficacy of Itepekimab in managing COPD symptoms over an extended period of time. 
Additionally, the St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) total score and domain scores assess the overall burden of COPD on participants' health-related quality of life, while the EuroQol-5 Dimensions-5 Level (EQ-5D-5L) and the EuroQol Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS) are used to assess health-related quality of life from different perspectives. These outcome measures provide a comprehensive assessment of the impact of Itepekimab therapy on participants' quality of life. 
In summary

Of course. The Post-BD FEV1, SGRQ total score, and domain scores measures help assess the drug's efficacy on COPD symptoms and outcomes, while the EQ-5D-5L single index score and EQ-VAS measures help assess the drug's impact on health-related quality of life (HRQOL). Finally, the change in CASA-Q is a measure of participant-reported outcomes (PROs) that helps understand the impact of the intervention on daily living activities and overall symptom burden. 
Maintaining healthy blood glucose levels improves cardiovascular mortality, hospitalizations for heart failure, and stroke/TIA in patients with type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. This meta-analysis will explore the hypothesis that cardiovascular risk reduction with good glycemic control is similar for people of all ethnicities.
INTRODUCTION
Background
Making informed choices about diabetes care requires a clear understanding of the risks and benefits of different interventions for achieving good glycemic control. In a recent meta-analysis examining cardiovascular risk factors in patients with type 2 diabetes, the investigators found that glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was significantly lower in ethnic minorities. Non-white racial categories included Asian, American Indian/Alaska Native, African American, and other racial and ethnic minorities were included in the study. Although the absolute values were lower than those of other ethnic groups, there were no significant differences in 8-year cardiovascular mortality rate between black Caribbean and British whites or Hispanics and non-Hispanic whites.1 A recent study focusing on Asian Americans found that the highest HbA1c was in patients of South Asian and other Asian ancestry and the lowest in East Asian descendents.2 It has also been shown that African Americans are more insulin resistant than other populations, which may help explain why they have a higher risk for cardiovascular disease compared with other groups.3

PURPOSE OF THE RESEARCH
The purpose of this study is to conduct a meta-analysis to determine whether maintaining blood glucose levels in the normal range is as beneficial to patients with type 2 diabetes in terms of cardiovascular protection as it is to people of other racial and ethnic backgrounds who are less likely to develop cardiovascular disease.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of the study is to evaluate the effect of pre-training stretching on muscle function and strength among competitive ballet dancers before, during, and after a day of rehearsal during their three-hour ballet session.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Participants will perform an hour-long dance session followed by three hours of stretching. Five minutes before performing a task, participants will perform the standardized warm-up. After completing the task, they will repeat all measurements. Three hours later, the participants will repeat the same procedure. Participants will be asked to perform a full day of rehearsal in their usual way. They will measure their stretching performance before, during, and after the rehearsal. The participant's stretching routine will be recorded before, during, and after the rehearsal to ensure that it is done properly. The study will be conducted in a private room to prevent the participants from falling asleep. The stretching duration for each muscle group will be recorded, and a timer will be used to ensure that each muscle group is stretched properly. To record the duration of stretching, the researcher will observe the participant and ensure that the duration is not greater than 3 minutes. The participants will perform a set of tests to measure their performance. These include an arm hanging test, a squat strength test, and a plank strength test. The test procedure is fully detailed in the protocol. The participant will be asked to sit on a chair with their feet on the ground while their hands are holding onto a bar. These positions will be repeated for 30 seconds twice.

Official Title
-----------------
The Effect of Pre-training Stretching on Muscle Function and Strength Among Competitive Ballet Dancers

-----------------
Stretching

1. Retention: This measure will assess the clinical performance of the CAD/CAM endocrown restorations over time and determine the number of restorations that remain intact and in place. This will be measured using an 18-point scoring system. 
2. Marginal discoloration: This measure will assess the extent of discoloration along the margins of the restorations and will be measured using a visual assessment of color matching at each tooth site. 
3. Marginal adaptation: This measure will assess the extent of adaptation of the restoration margins to the surrounding tooth structure and will be measured using an 18-point visual scoring system. 
4. Secondary caries: This measure will assess the incidence of secondary caries affecting the adjacent tooth structure and will be measured using a visual assessment of the presence or absence of secondary caries. 

The investigators will evaluate these outcome measures at baseline, one year, and two years post-restoration. The outcomes will be analyzed using descriptive statistics and compared between the experimental and control groups using unpaired t-tests or the Mann-Whitney U test, as appropriate.
Do you have a draft available for this section of the protocol? If so, is it in good shape for release?

For marginal discoloration, we'll be using visual measurements as assessed by two independent evaluators. The scales of assessment will include the following: 1=color match, no marginal discoloration visible at the margin, 2=slight discoloration, discoloration less than half the peripheral length, 3=moderate discoloration, discoloration more than half the peripheral length, and 4=severe discoloration, discoloration exceeding the periphery. 

It's essential to accurately measure marginal discoloration to ensure that the restorations meet the aesthetic expectations of both the patient and the clinician. Using a standardized measurement system ensures that the assessment criteria are consistent and reliable, which is crucial for the success of the study. 

[/P] Overall, the standardized evaluation process and measurement tools will provide a robust assessment of the outcome measures, which will help us to determine the effect of the novel restorative technique.

Marginal adaptation is the extent to which the restoration contours fit the tooth and how well it adapts to the shape of the underlying tooth structure. We'll evaluate marginal adaptation using a periodontal probe to assess the integrity of the marginal seal. We'll use the following scores: Alfa for no adaption problems, Bravo for minor adaption problems, and Charlie for significant adaption problems. The evaluation will be performed by two independent clinicians. It will be conducted from baseline to 24 months. 
[Image: https://cdn.amespublishing.com/s3files/prod/journals/jdd/K-22-0169/JDD-D-22-00587/gbl03.jpg](https://cdn.amespublishing.com/s3files/prod/journals/jdd/K-22-0169/JDD-D-22-00587/gbl03.jpg)
[/Figure not available: see fulltext.](/Figure not available: see fulltext.)

Marginal discoloration will be assessed using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria from baseline to 24 months. The evaluation will be conducted by two independent clinicians. The scores will be Alfa for no discoloration (no pigmentation in restoration base and composite material), Bravo for discoloration without penetration in pulpal direction (no pigmentation in composite material), and Charlie for discoloration with penetration in pulpal direction (opacification at composite marginal gap).


[Image: https://cdn.amespublishing.com/s3files/prod/journals/jdd/K-22-0169/JDD-D-22-00587/gbl04.jpg](https://cdn.amespublishing.com/s3files/prod/journals/jdd/K-22-0169/JDD-D-22-00587/gbl04.jpg)
[/Figure not available: see fulltext.](/Figure not available: see fulltext.)



E.2.5.2 Secondary end point(s): Dentin hypersensitivity

Secondary caries is the recurrence of carious lesions around the restoration margins, which can weaken the restoration and lead to its failure. We'll evaluate it using the modified United States Public Health Service criteria. Two independent clinicians will visually inspect the restorations and rate them according to the following criteria: Alfa for none, Bravo for questionable, and Charlie for definite. Our previous studies have shown that none of the selected outcome measures have been significantly affected by the interim effect. We'll assess secondary caries at two time points: six months and 24 months. 

[Image: https://cdn.amespublishing.com/s3files/prod/journals/jdd/K-22-0169/JDD-D-22-00587/gbl03.jpg](https://cdn.amespublishing.com/s3files/prod/journals/jdd/K-22-0169/JDD-D-22-00587/gbl03.jpg)

During the four visits, participants will be required to brush their teeth a total of three times. The first two times will be during the study flow, as described above. The third and final brushing session will be performed at the patient's home, two days after the second treatment session, after which the participant will return to the clinic for postoperative recovery.

The study flowchart summarizes the clinical trial procedures that participants will be subjected to as part of the study (see Appendix A for a detailed description of each procedure).

Abstract:
Grapefruit juice can increase the absorption of some drugs. The aim of this prospective study was to evaluate the pharmacokinetics of acyclovir and valacyclovir administered with or without grapefruit juice in human volunteers. Acyclovir and valacyclovir 400 mg was administered as tablets to 16 healthy volunteers. Grapefruit juice was administered concomitantly. Blood samples were taken at 0, 12, 24, 48 h. The mean C(max) values after acyclovir (19.0 mug/ml ± 2.0 mug/ml) and valacyclovir (18.6 mug/ml ± 1.6 mug/ml) were increased (39.2 mug/ml ± 5.0 mug/ml and 36.0 mug/ml ± 3.7 mug/ml, respectively), and these drugs are absorbed from the stomach to the small intestine because of the increased bioavailability. Grapefruit juice may increase the absorption of drugs, such as acyclovir and valacyclovir, from the stomach to the small intestine and exerts effects on drug absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.

Study of a Novel Osteosynthesis Composite for the Fixation of the Clavicle 45-65Yrs

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of the study is to define the efficacy and safety of a novel osteosynthesis composite compared to a standard implant based on 3D-MCT scan evaluation and clinical follow up results in a randomized, multi-centre trial. In addition, radiostereometric analyses (RSA) will be performed at 6 months and 1 year to compare the amount of bone formation between the new and old implants and the amount of bone resorption between both implants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Patients above the age of 18 with a stable, distal Clavicle fracture are recruited and randomly assigned to the investigational composite for 3 months non-removable fixation or to a standard platinum-coated non-removable titanium implant. Post operatively, patients will be evaluated clinically at 1 week, 3 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 year respectively. To assess implant safety, patients will undergo standardized plain x-rays at all time points. A 3D-MCT is taken at 3 months and 1 year after surgery. Radiostereometric analyses (RSA) will be performed at 6 months and 1 year of follow-up to assess implant fixation and the amount of bone formation as well as bone resorption between control patients and patients with the investigational implant.

Official Title
-----------------
Study of a Novel Osteosynthesis Composite for the Fixation of the Clavicle Non-Randomized. RSA-Comparison of 3 Months Fixation With a Standard Platinum Titanium to One-Year Fixation With a Bioactive Clavicle Composite(TK-NCF).

Conditions

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Device: TK-NCF
* Device: Standard Platinum Tit

=================
Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, with an estimated 18.1 million new cases and 9 million deaths in 2018 . Solid tumors account for the majority of cancer cases, and treatment options are often limited or ineffective, especially for patients with advanced or metastatic disease . Immunotherapies have revolutionized cancer therapy in recent years, but many patients still experience suboptimal responses or treatment-related toxicities. VISTA, a checkpoint receptor, is a promising potential target for immunotherapy . Aim
The aim of the study is to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and efficacy of SNS-101 (anti-VISTA) as a monotherapy and in combination with cemiplimab in patients with advanced solid tumors. Design

The use of 18F‐FDG‐PET/CT for the assessment of early tumor response to anti‐tumor treatment is increasingly reported as the superiority over conventional imaging (MRI / CT) is demonstrated. With the approval of the FDA's PET‐response criteria in 2009, PET‐CRC as the only dedicated imaging response criteria have been established. Based on these encouraging results, the EU has now set up a consortium (IMPRESS‐2) that aims to evaluate and apply oncological PET tracers in clinical routine. In the first step, the study aims to compare 2 oncological PET tracers ‐ 18F‐FLT and 18F‐FET‐PET/CT for detection of early response in patients with colorectal cancer after neoadjuvant therapy. 60 patients with colorectal carcinoma who receive neoadjuvant treatment are prospectively followed for 6 months, taking into account 4 different time nodes (1 month, 2 months, 4 months and 6 months). The tumor response will be evaluated by means of PET‐CRC, TNM and RECIST 1.1, as well as histopathology. The results will be presented in an interim analysis. The subsequent study section will investigate the best PET tracer in a randomized comparison with regard to inter‐ and intra‐observer variability, intra‐ and inter‐scanner variability, diagnostic performance and reproducibility. The planned PET tracer selection for clinical routine is to be compared with other established imaging procedures (MRI / CT, diffusion-weighted MRI), whereby the aim is a decision for oncological response criteria. Our study group is experienced and has previously published on this topic. As a result, the DOACs are considered a standard of care for atrial fibrillation, venous thrombosis, and, more recently, for coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Atrial fibrillation

Intervention
=================
Renal Denervation is a non-destructive, minimally invasive, catheter-based technology intended to selectively reduce the high blood pressure through the denervation of the sympathetic nerves to the renal arteries. Renal denervation is conducted during the same procedure as catheter ablation of atrial fibrillation.

Intervention type
=================
Device

Primary outcome measure
=================
1. Primary outcome measure: Hospitalization rate for atrial fibrillation (AF);

Secondary outcome measures
=================
1. Efficacy (atrial fibrillation rates);
2. Safety (complications associated with the procedure);
3. Efficacy and safety of renal denervation in combination with left atrial substrate modification or pulmonary vein isolation.

Participant inclusion criteria
=================
1. Participants with atrial fibrillation treated with catheter ablation and renal denervation procedures.
Participant type(s): Patient
Age group: Adult
Sex: Both
Target number of participants: 50

Participant exclusion criteria
=================
1. Active systemic infection at the time of treatment;
2. Any condition that would make the patient excessively thrombogenic (e.g., heparin or aspirin allergy), in which case the patient must not participate in this study;
3. Any additional medical conditions that might preclude the use of the renal denervation catheter (examples: abdominal aortic aneurysm, abdominal aortic occlusion, any renal mass, renal cyst);
4. Impaired systemic hemostasis;
5. Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: The role of renal denervation in improving clinical outcomes in patients with symptomatic paroxysmal atrial fibrillation despite durable pulmonary vein isolation has not been fully elucidated.OBJECTIVE: We investigated the long‐term safety, efficacy, and the effect on health‐related quality of life of renal denervation in patients with recurrent paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who had undergone durable pulmonary vein isolation.METHODS: In the present study, we examined 77 patients who had undergone renal denervation through a transfemoral approach after a pulmonary vein isolation procedure. Before the procedure, patients completed a quality of life questionnaire. They were treated with a single session of radiofrequency catheter ablation of the renal arteries. The primary endpoint of the study was the cumulative atrial fibrillation burden 12 months after percutaneous renal denervation.RESULTS: At the end of the follow‐up period (12‐month post‐ablation), all patients (n=77) showed a significant reduction in atrial fibrillation burden. Among the patients who experienced one or more documented episodes of atrial fibrillation during the first three months after renal denervation, a significant decrease in atrial fibrillation burden was noted, ranging from 54.2% to 95.9% (p< 0.05). Furthermore, there was a significant increase in patients with a sustained AF burden <5%.CONCLUSIONS: Renal denervation, in addition to a pulmonary vein isolation procedure, effectively prevents atrial fibrillation recurrence in patients who have experienced atrial fibrillation recurrence within the first three months after an initial ablation procedure.

We recommend measuring these parameters at baseline, during heating, immediately after heating, and at 1, 4, and 8 hours post-heating. This will allow us to track the changes in physiological parameters over time. Does this schedule sound appropriate to you? 

Study
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
A clinical trial with 10 participants. The subjects will receive passive heating for 45 minutes. The physiological parameters will be measured at baseline, during heating, immediately after heating, and at 1, 4, and 8 hours post-heating to evaluate the changes in response to passive heating. The control group will receive no intervention.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study aims to determine the effects of passive heating on physiological responses, including core temperature, oxygen consumption, cardiac output, blood pressure, and heart rate. The subjects will be assigned either the experimental group (passive heating for 45 minutes) or the control group (no intervention). The physiological parameters will be measured using the CorTemp™ smart pill, Bair Hugger® system, Finopres© system, and open circuit spirometer. Data analysis will be performed using statistical methods to compare the results between the groups and determine the impact of passive heating on physiological responses. Recruitment: 20 participants in total (10 in each group) Informed consent will be obtained before enrolling the subjects. The study will be conducted in a controlled environment with the subjects lying down and resting comfortably in a supine position. The experimental group will receive passive heating using a hot water bottle or body wrap for 45 minutes. For the control group, there will be no intervention. All subjects will be monitored for any adverse effects. There is a risk of mild discomfort during the passive heating intervention, but no known serious risks are associated with it. This study is expected to take approximately 2-3 months to complete, including data analysis and publication.

Effects of Passive Heating on Physiological Responses

Two hundred seventy‐seven primary ESS patients and 316 revision ESS patients had been previously included in our study. Primary ESS patients had significantly more septal turbinates (P = .029) and had lower ESS scores (P = .001) than revision ESS patients. There were no significant differences between the two groups concerning intraoperative events, postoperative events, or hospital admission. The overall complication rate was not different between primary ESS and revision ESS patients.

Intervention Description:: The primary outcome measure of the trial is tooth survival, which is defined as the maintenance of pulpal vitality and the absence of clinical and radiographic signs of pulp necrosis or failure. The study includes two interventions: a test intervention—the use of sodiumhexametaphosphate as a pulp capping material—and a control intervention—the use of MTA as a pulp capping material. Both test and control material are delivered in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions. All participants receive one application of the test material or control material under local anesthesia. The test material is delivered in a cavity preparation on the pulp surface to cover the exposed pulp and achieve a tight seal. No removal or drilling is done, as these procedures may result in pulp infection. 
Follow-up visits are scheduled at 6 months, 12 months, and 18 months after the pulp therapy procedure. At each visit, the tooth is examined clinically and radiographically to assess pulpal healing and the absence of pulp necrosis. Radiographic evidence of pulp necrosis or failure includes focal widening of the periodontal ligament space, periapical radiolucency greater than 5 mm or indefinite in size or shape, and non-occluded radiolucent defects.[31] Additional interventions are performed as needed, such as root canal treatment or extraction.[32]

# Pulp Capping Materials in Primary Teeth: A Randomized Clinical Trial
Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Background and Aims Dental pulp is the soft tissue that resides within the central part of the tooth. Its main function is to provide nutrients to the tooth and help maintain its vitality. When the dental pulp encounters injury or infection, it can become inflamed and diseased, leading to pulp death and tooth loss. Pulp capping is a dental procedure that aims to prevent pulp death and preserve the tooth by covering the injured or exposed pulp with a material that promotes healing and protects the remaining viable tissue. MTA (Mineral Trioxide Aggregate) and sodiumhexametaphosphate are both commonly used pulp capping materials in primary teeth. However, MTA has several advantages over sodiumhexametaphosphate, including better physical properties, better sealing ability, and a lower risk of leakage. Previous studies have shown that pulpal healing rates and successful outcomes are high with both MTA and sodiumhexametaphosphate, but no significant differences have been reported between them. Therefore, the aim of this study is to assess which pulp capping material is more effective in managing pulpal necrosis of primary teeth. Hypothesis The null hypothesis is that there is no difference between the two pulp capping materials in terms of clinical success rate over one year. Methodology A multi-center, parallel, randomized, controlled clinical trial will be conducted in pediatric dentistry clinics in Iran. A total of 150 children aged 3-6 years with pulp necrosis of primary teeth will be recruited and randomly assigned to either MTA or sodiumhexametaphosphate (SHMP) groups. Both materials will be applied to the injured pulp by the same operator, and the clinical success of the procedure will be evaluated for one year following treatment. Primary and secondary outcome measures Clinical outcome measures will include

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: There is a growing concern over the health risks associated with consuming high fat and sugary foods. This randomised controlled trial tested the effectiveness of an educational intervention, involving a parenting‐focused nutrition programme (PNP), plus an intervention arm (which received the regular PNP intervention alongside the additional nutritional information) on improving knowledge and confidence, and changing nutrition‐related behaviours in parents of children aged 7‐11 years.METHODS: Parents (n = 290) were recruited from two primary schools in South East London. One school was randomly allocated an intervention group, while the other was a control group. The Intervention consisted of a seven‐session nutrition programme plus the routine school nutritional information. The control condition received the regular PNP intervention. The study measured parent knowledge, confidence, self‐efficacy, nutrition behaviours, general lifestyle, and their self‐perceived ability to provide a healthy, balanced diet for their child.RESULTS: Findings suggest that parents in the intervention group displayed improved knowledge, self‐efficacy, and dietary behaviours compared to parents in the control group. However, changes were not maintained after six months.CONCLUSIONS: Although the results are inconsistent, the study suggests that the PNP intervention is an effective tool for improving parental nutrition knowledge and health behaviours in young children. The inclusion of this educational intervention in the school environment, along with nutritional information, could prove to be a valuable tool in promoting healthy eating behaviours in children and their families

Introduction
Cervical cancer is a common cancer and the third most common type of cancer in women worldwide (1). It is estimated that 604,000 new cases will be diagnosed globally in 2022, with over half of these cases occurring in developing countries (1). Cervical cancer is a major public health issue, accounting for 7.5% of all cancer deaths in women (2). Surgery is the most common treatment for early-stage cervical cancer (3). However, it can have significant physical and psychological consequences for patients, including pain, discomfort, and anxiety (3).
Warm compress, defined as the application of a warm water bottle or heat pack on the pelvic region, has been used for pain relief in various contexts, including menstrual cramps, back pain, and musculoskeletal disorders (4). It is believed that the thermal effect of warm compress helps to stimulate blood circulation, reduce muscle tension, and provide a soothing sensation (4). There is limited evidence on the use of warm compress for pain relief during surgery in patients with cervical cancer (5). However, it has been reported that warm compress can help to alleviate pain and improve patient satisfaction (5).
The aim of this study is to investigate the effectiveness of warm compress for pain management during surgery in patients with early-stage cervical cancer. The main objective of the study is to compare the pain intensity level of patients who receive warm compress during surgery with those who do not receive warm compress. The secondary objectives are to compare the postoperative recovery time, postoperative complications, and patient satisfaction level between the two study groups. 

Materials and methods
A double-blinded randomized clinical trial will be conducted at a tertiary care hospital in India. The study will be conducted after obtaining Institutional Ethics Committee approval and written informed consent from all participants.
The study will be conducted on female patients undergoing surgery for early-stage cervical cancer. The inclusion criteria will be patients who are diagnosed with clinical stage I and II Cervical Cancer and willing to participate in the study. The exclusion criteria will be patients who are pregnant, have a history of pre-existing skin conditions or allerg

The length of labor should be measured from the start of the application of warm compress until delivery. This will capture the impact of warm compression on the duration of labor.

The outcome measure will be the duration of the second stage of labor.

5. Spontaneous spontaneous vaginal delivery

=================
1. Multiple gestations
2. Anesthesia at any stage of labor
3. Cholestasis
4. Active infections
5. Fetal birth defects

Abstract:
Background Current evidence suggests that the introduction of electronic health record systems has yielded ineffective interventions, resulting in physicians devoting a less substantial amount of time to the medical history and physical examination. The purpose of this study was to determine the use of electronic medical records for the inactive diagnosis of uncontrolled hypertension among patients without a history of hypertension. Method Patients, identified using two physician practices medical record systems, were 30 years and older. The 2012 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey norms were used to determine those patients who had an uncontrolled diagnosis of hypertension according to mean systolic and diastolic blood pressure values. Results The mean age was 48 years, and most were women (64%). The majority of patients had an uncontrolled diagnosis of hypertension according to SBP and DBP values in the 2012 NHANES survey norm (67% and 87%, respectively). Approximately two‐thirds of the patients with an uncontrolled diagnosis of hypertension had a recorded blood pressure reading of <140 or <90 mmHg in their electronic health records. Conclusions Our study found that more than half of the patients with an uncontrolled diagnosis of hypertension had an inaccurately recorded blood pressure value, and these errors were not identified in the electronic record system. The results suggest that physicians must rely more on the manual evaluation of patients in order to provide appropriate care and improve clinical outcomes.

Abstract:
Objectives : Decision‐making in cancer is very complex. The objective of this retrospective, observational study was to investigate a possible role for the patient's decision‐making style in the survival time of patients with resectable metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. Methods : Survival data from a cohort of patients with pancreatic cancer were obtained from the German‐Austrian pancreas database. The patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma were dichotomized according to their decision‐making style. Cox proportional hazard analysis and Kaplan‐Meier analysis were used to analyze the survival of the patients. Results : Data from 221 patients with resectable metastatic adenocarcinoma of the pancreas were analyzed. The median age of the patients was 59 years (range , 29‐76 years). Seventy‐six of the patients (34%) followed a collaborative decision‐making style, whereas 145 patients (66%) made independent decisions, 3 patients (1%) followed a passive decision‐making style, and 7 patients (3%) followed a supportive decision‐making style. A multivariate analysis showed that an independent decision‐making style was an independent prognostic factor for overall survival (hazard ratio (HR) , 1.91 [95% confidence interval (CI) , 1.20‐3.04]; P=0.006). Kaplan‐Meier analysis showed that patients with a collaborative decision‐making style had a significantly longer median overall survival than patients with an independent decision‐making style (27.3 months versus 17.8 months; P=0.027). However, the median overall survival for patients with an independent decision‐making style who underwent pancreatectomy was 33.1

Description

There are many complications in peripancreatic collection such as gas leakage, abscess, pseudocyst, duodenal fistula and pancreatic fistula after surgery. In Korea, intraoperative drainage of peripancreatic collection and postoperative close observation and treatment are performed in order to prevent fistula. However, in such cases, the time to fistula occurrence is 1 to 50 days, and the time required for fistula treatment is 2 to 6 weeks. There are a variety of methods of treatment due to the different time point of treatment, location of the drain, type and method of observation, location and time of examination, and the degree of accuracy of diagnosis due to imaging. In particular, the current diagnostic criteria for postoperative pancreatic fistula are based on the clinical diagnosis of IHPBA (International Study Group on Pancreatic Fistula), rather than the method of radiological examination. The International Study Group on Pancreatic Fistula (ISGPF) defines postoperative pancreatic fistula (POPF) as the following: (1) at least an 8 cm (23 mL) increase in serum amylase (or lipase) concentration compared to normal at least 3 days after operation; (2) amylase level greater than 300 IU/L without evidence of intra-abdominal infection (such as peritonitis, abscess and organ ischemia); (3) Drainage fluid amylase greater than 3 times the serum amylase at any time or 10 times the serum amylase if a drain is present in the absence of infection. This method is mainly used because surgical site infection in the postoperative period makes it difficult to distinguish from pancreatic tissue.
